La comprensione del concetto di "deficit di attenzione" è fondamentale per una corretta diagnosi e intervento nei disturbi dello sviluppo e dell'apprendimento. Questo termine, tuttavia, è spesso utilizzato in modo impreciso, confondendolo con l'impulsività o l'iperattività, che rappresentano aspetti specifici del Disturbo da Deficit di Attenzione e Iperattività (ADHD).

Il deficit di attenzione, in senso stretto, si riferisce a una difficoltà persistente nel mantenere l'attenzione, organizzare i compiti, seguire le istruzioni e completare le attività. Si manifesta con sintomi quali: distrazione frequente, difficoltà a concentrarsi su un compito specifico, scarsa capacità di pianificazione e organizzazione, tendenza a dimenticare appuntamenti o impegni, e difficoltà a resistere alle distrazioni esterne.

È importante sottolineare che il deficit di attenzione non è necessariamente legato a una ridotta intelligenza o a una mancanza di volontà. Può essere causato da una varietà di fattori, tra cui predisposizione genetica, disfunzioni neurobiologiche, lesioni cerebrali o influenze ambientali.

La valutazione del deficit di attenzione richiede un approccio multidisciplinare che coinvolga medici, psicologi, pedagogisti e altri professionisti. La diagnosi si basa sull'osservazione del comportamento del bambino o dell'adulto, sull'anamnesi familiare e personale, e sull'utilizzo di test standardizzati.

Il trattamento del deficit di attenzione può includere interventi farmacologici, terapie comportamentali, supporto psicologico e modifiche ambientali. L'obiettivo è migliorare le capacità di attenzione e concentrazione, ridurre i sintomi correlati e favorire il successo scolastico e sociale.

La teoria della relatività generale di Einstein, pubblicata nel 1915, descrive la gravità non come una forza, ma come una conseguenza della curvatura dello spazio-tempo causata dalla massa e dall'energia.

In questa teoria, la presenza di materia ed energia deforma lo spazio-tempo, e questa deformazione è ciò che percepiamo come gravità. Oggetti massivi, come stelle e pianeti, creano una “depressione” nello spazio-tempo, e altri oggetti si muovono lungo le geodetiche, che sono i percorsi più brevi in questo spazio-tempo curvo.

La relatività generale ha implicazioni profonde per la nostra comprensione dell'universo, tra cui la previsione di fenomeni come i buchi neri, le onde gravitazionali e l'espansione dell'universo. Queste previsioni sono state successivamente confermate da osservazioni sperimentali, consolidando la posizione della teoria come una delle pietre miliari della fisica moderna.

Un concetto chiave della relatività generale è il principio di equivalenza, che afferma che l'accelerazione e la gravità sono indistinguibili localmente. Questo principio ha portato Einstein a formulare la sua teoria della relatività generale, unificando le leggi della gravità con la geometria dello spazio-tempo.

La verifica sperimentale della relatività generale ha coinvolto una serie di esperimenti, tra cui la misurazione della deflessione della luce delle stelle durante un'eclissi solare e la verifica del rallentamento del tempo in presenza di un campo gravitazionale intenso. Questi risultati hanno fornito una forte evidenza a sostegno della teoria di Einstein.



Einstein’s general theory of relativity, published in 1915, describes gravity not as a force, but as a consequence of the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.

In this theory, the presence of matter and energy deforms spacetime, and this deformation is what we perceive as gravity. Massive objects, such as stars and planets, create a “depression” in spacetime, and other objects move along geodesics, which are the shortest paths in this curved spacetime.

General relativity has profound implications for our understanding of the universe, including the prediction of phenomena such as black holes, gravitational waves, and the expansion of the universe. These predictions have subsequently been confirmed by experimental observations, solidifying the theory's position as one of the cornerstones of modern physics.

A key concept of general relativity is the equivalence principle, which states that acceleration and gravity are indistinguishable locally. This principle led Einstein to formulate his theory of general relativity, unifying the laws of gravity with the geometry of spacetime.

Experimental verification of general relativity has involved a series of experiments, including the measurement of the deflection of starlight during a solar eclipse and the verification of the slowing of time in the presence of a strong gravitational field. These results have provided strong evidence in support of Einstein’s theory.

Mr. President, reading the text of this document gives the impression that its author does not seek improvement, but rather a deterioration of relations between the European Union and Russia.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, allow me first to greet the President of the DTP Party, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the Honour Gallery and who is following the debate.

Dear Ahmet, please know that we stand in solidarity with you, and we support the democratic struggle that your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize in DTP an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey and, for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that the
Prime Minister Erdoğan has ordered against you, incarcerating all three deputy leaders of the DTP, along with over 300 militants and supporters.
The victory of the DTP in the most recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP Party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on President Erdoğan to initiate direct discussions with the DTP, yet his response has been further repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the left-wing "Europe Now" have thus far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while simultaneously advocating for the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdoğan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish military, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling with Kurds, and Erdoğan himself, who is closing off any prospect of Turkey’s accession.
Only he bears the responsibility for what is happening in the Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message: Erdoğan must make the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority, making it absolutely clear through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to request the suspension of Turkey’s accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path to Turkey’s accession to the Union passes through Davos and through the DTP; otherwise, we—those who have thus far supported the accession process—will be the ones to call for a period of reflection that risks becoming definitive.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, and I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament presided over by you.
I believe that the sacrifices made twenty years ago in her country and that those twelve countries now represent in this assembly give strength to Europe.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is neither my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and desired this debate, to transfer matters of Italian domestic policy to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, regarding the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counter political and economic influences and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where even the owner of some of the most important private networks is involved, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, should serve to protect the pluralism of information, avoiding concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Madam President, honourable colleagues, I am aware that last September 30th the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report drafted by Marianne Mikko was voted on, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, I quote, "the multiplicity."
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diverse information sources.

Earlier still, in 2004, a report by Bogert Quack on the risks of infringement within the European Union of freedom of expression and information was voted on in Parliament, wherein the Commission was requested to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has yet to provide clear answers to the requests of Parliament.

Please note, Commissioner, that I have not named my country nor my Prime Minister, but in this forum, as a European citizen, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.

Mr. President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the hopeful smile of the Palestinian representatives.
They were intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on Hebron's street, the ghost street that no Palestinian can traverse.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent located in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funding, subsequently destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The Council of Europe’s decision marks a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day and during the visit, Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to ensure that the voice of democratic Europe is heard.

Lord, I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we spent in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine have been able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, honourable members, the theme of fiscal good governance, although always of great importance, has taken on significantly greater topicality following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International leaders, including the G20 and European summits, have discussed it and continue to do so, particularly when addressing tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, it is a sign of commitment and willpower, but one must not entertain illusions that an announcement alone is sufficient.
A serious and consistent policy is required.
Many problems remain.
It is truly still too easy to purchase or establish a shell company for tax evasion.
Simply do an internet search. There are thousands of websites offering companies for acquisition, even in countries within the European Union.
Often, it is sufficient to send an email with a scanned copy of the passport attached to open a company.
It is necessary to put an end to the practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation.
This report that I present is based on the communication from the European Commission on fiscal good governance of 28 April 2009.
The report aims to advance concrete proposals and requests a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
It is necessary to consider the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and the illicit flight of capital as a priority for the European Union.
From this, the principle of good governance, which is founded on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that increasingly greater tax cooperation and collaboration are needed within the European Union.
The overarching objective we must set for ourselves is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, naturally starting with the European Union.
As the colleague Alvarez has already stated, banking secrecy must be abolished entirely in European Union countries, and an end must be put to the derogation regime without further delay.

Take into account the individuals or enterprises that have created companies or opened accounts in tax havens, reaffirm and relaunch tax harmonization projects beginning with this.

Sir, I must admit that when we discuss the fight against terrorism, focusing solely on intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wished to cure a disease by concentrating only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not perhaps time to address the problem of terrorism, aiming at the heart of the matter rather than limiting oneself to its outward phenomenology?

Addressing the core of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or new unwillingness of influential groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask and I request of this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
To this end, I have submitted a question to the Commission to encourage this Assembly to openly address the issue.
It appears there is no willingness whatsoever to address the subject.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the conclusion of negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is an achievable objective, and the Švoboda report highlights, in a balanced manner, the progress made and the steps still required.
Now is the time for justice, the sector in which decisive reforms are still needed.
It is not enough, indeed, to complete the necessary systemic reforms and to approve new laws and to cooperate as needed with the tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the necessity of creating a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, a central issue, becomes crucial, as does the training, recruitment, and career progression of judges—that is, the absence of any form of influence exerted by the government upon them.
I urge the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiations.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the tenth anniversary of Croatia and its accession to the European Union underscores the consolidation of a European identity capable of expressing the shared values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating, the specificities of its many facets.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts to align with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but needs to undertake further efforts, especially within the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further progress can be made by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with what is provided for in the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in 1952, by evaluating the restitution of nationalized assets to their legitimate owners.

justice that has harshly condemned Italy, which failed to manage waste disposal in Campania. The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and for many months worldwide.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to reiterate once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed alongside four other parliamentarians and which a majority of the European Parliament has approved, in order to obligate the Council and the Commission to enact truly effective legislation concerning corruption.

I have returned on behalf of the budgetary control committee from a visit to Greece, and it is certainly the case that one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis also stems from the squandering of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

I flee from corruption, as emerges in these days, corruption that circulates primarily through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a portion of the political class and a portion of the business community, and organized white-collar crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all of its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States; Member States that do not comply should be sanctioned, and the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime should be strengthened.
For masculine and feminine genders, we know well that this difference is even more pronounced within the sphere of autonomous activities.
Indeed, women have all too often been compelled to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role or the workload that stems from absolute dedication to family.

To resolve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping the guiding star of the family firmly in view—only this can give meaning and hope of success to these very measures.

Freeing women from the distressing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of family work and directly addressing concrete issues through positive and specific measures to support families.
Placing the family at the center is essential; otherwise, any package of measures will be an uncoordinated collection of interventions, ultimately futile.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, colleagues, Commissioner, we are already discussing organ transplantation, which certainly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare field.
But it also opens up a whole series of problems concerning the rights of the donor and the patient that must be addressed on ethical, social, legal, and economic grounds.

It is a matter of activating a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between needs and the quantity of available organs, without compromising the principle of free and voluntary donation, hindering

form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, guaranteeing the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that effectively balance confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplantation systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European database and adopt common standards of quality and security.
We must, however, be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create further bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently carried out correctly and effectively.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, 170 measures in five years—numbers too ambitious, furthermore, a programme lacking a genuine character, especially regarding certain issues.

On immigration, and the program, beyond the official documents, reveals an embarrassing beauty. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if a political strategy is then lacking?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key points: combating irregular immigration along the southern border, sharing responsibility among all European states and entities in countering irregular migration, a policy of agreements with third countries, and, above all, the recognition that immigration during times of crisis is not an asset.
From the parliamentary frenzy, we read that more than twenty percent of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the Committee on Internal Affairs states that the issue of immigration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, one must reason with concreteness and realism. Today, the priority is to provide employment for our citizens; everything else is sentimental rhetoric that neither aids in the integration of immigrants nor, indeed, our own people.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This concerns the first regulation on passenger rights via bus and should guarantee passengers, as happens in the rail and air sectors.
The second reading position aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I concur with the speaker Cancian’s line of argument, whom I thank for the excellent work performed, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passenger rights in the event of accidents, cancellations, or departure delays, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the matter of information regarding passenger rights. It would indeed be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transportation. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services via bus and those via rail.

Regarding individuals with disabilities and those with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee maximum protection, and I would propose a 24-hour timeframe instead of 48, in order to request assistance and greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of the equipment that ensures the mobility of individuals with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers and those with reduced mobility, any architectural barrier should be eliminated and existing infrastructure improved to ensure accessibility.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve passenger travel conditions.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on this report, which deals with extending free circulation in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I concur with the rapporteur regarding the purpose of this directive, namely to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

Indeed, to achieve a borderless European maritime space, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied simultaneously.
This is necessary to guarantee the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to ensure that sea freight transport is more attractive and used in an optimal manner.

The harmonisation of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will revitalise maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed upon it.
Electronic systems should therefore be activated as quickly as possible, as this would enable a faster data exchange system.

Furthermore, interoperability is essential for achieving genuine administrative simplification. Indeed, initiating information exchange via email is not entirely efficient and proves futile if the information systems are not interoperable from a technical perspective.
Regarding language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be expedited, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Honorable colleagues, the road toward a Europe tailored to women is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak clearly: the global crisis has struck the labor market, severely testing female employment, which further decreased in 2008 by seven-tenths of a percentage point.

Despite the provocations on the subject of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a Europropaganda in decline, to date, no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women a genuine fulfillment, both as professionals and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model, and not merely periodically change its label.

Therefore, the directive aligning the maternity leave provision across Europe is underway, but it is inefficient to treat, within the same report, the complementary and equally important matter of paternity leave as a marginal issue.

Greater integration of women is not merely a moral value but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-touted European social model, which continues not to convince me due to the lack of results.

During 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had requested that Parliament approve an amendment allowing non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
Correspondence from our office accepted.
But the cooperation and development regulations also contain the implementing rules for the European Union’s development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission needs to allocate funding, it must follow comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine this proposed funding and, should the Commission exceed its remit, Parliament may then adopt resolutions to request the Commission to modify the decisions in question.

Only since 2006 to the present has Parliament considered, in at least twelve instances, that the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its draft decision.
Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the development committee proposed applying the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in strategic financing decisions that the European Commission must adopt, the Parliament would have a more significant role.
Indeed, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in certain, well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions, but what might these decisions be?
In our view, the selection of countries to which the European Union should provide development assistance

It is a choice that rests with the legislator; and then, which sectors should be prioritized in funding: education, healthcare, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the areas and subjects in which the European Parliament should play a more significant role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislature must provide the executive with precise guidance.
and it is precisely this direction in which, ultimately, I believe the requests of European citizens are headed.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I thank honourable Meisner for the report on integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sphere.
Therefore, cooperation between small and large ports facing the same body of water should be encouraged, facilitating a smoother exchange of trade.
Furthermore, to ensure intermodality, investment is required in port and hinterland infrastructure, particularly that of ports which can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to neglect another theme, namely that of port security.

It is necessary that there be a homogenization of all safety measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and to prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports which, instead, in order to ensure greater security, must face higher expenses.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, thirty years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people. Today, it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.

No information and no representatives.

Europe watches passively.

There is no statement from Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
It is necessary to react with a statement of position from Parliament.
It is necessary to react toward Morocco, halting every initiative regarding commercial agreements, beginning with the renewal of fishing agreements.

I, too, join in thanking the honorable Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to finalize this complex report.
I believe what the honourable member recalled is particularly important.
Langen stated that we wish to maintain the purpose and scope of this regulation, remaining faithful to the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of
risk and speculation when it comes to what happened, exchanging and insuring 400 million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves. One understands the risks we run.

Having said this, however, I would also like to mention two problems. The first problem is the relationship with the Council. The second problem is the organic nature of the proposed reform of financial markets that we must pursue.

I raise the first issue concerning the Council, and I state it very clearly. The feeling is too often that the Council represents an obstacle to acting swiftly and effectively on the financial markets reform front.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this problem, because even on this occasion we must put in
a lengthening of timelines largely attributable to the positions, difficulties, and contrasts that arise within the Council.
a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow
The second matter concerns the organic and specific nature of the measures.
There is not only the measure concerning OTCs; there is also the measure concerning short selling and other matters.

I wish to recall two points: the specific question of the raw materials market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in European Union countries.
I believe these are issues on which Parliament must intervene.
Honorable members, the Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences with the release into the sea of radioactive water 6,500 times exceeding legal limits.
The risk of food products becoming contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this pertains exclusively to fresh products.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370,000 tons of canned tuna, and our primary suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information regarding the place of origin.
Today, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently recognized this and intends to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not take effect before two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not have effect before three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Ladies and gentlemen, President Tusk, your address gives us good hope; the hope is that the Polish Presidency will be a contribution to the fight against the Europe of egoisms.
national, without looking to the future, that it be a contribution in favor of Europe that truly considers itself as having an integrated reality and a common destiny.
But, as you rightly pointed out in your presentation, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and resolve.
I, in this brief time, wish to indicate to you two crucial issues regarding the economic and financial crisis.
First issue, the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem; it is a major democratic issue of our time. The times are too long. We must close issues such as those relating to the reform of short selling and derivatives.
Secondly, we have before us the topic of financial transaction taxation. We need to delve into the specifics; we expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
more than twenty years since the signing of the Dishenghel agreements.
No one doubts the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current structure is no longer adequate for present and future needs.

Therefore, the Member States, the EU, and all involved must commit to reviewing the operational mechanisms of Schengen, ensuring that freedom of movement does not compromise the legitimate security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know to date, the Commission's orientations may also be partially shareable, particularly with regard to the introduction of a mechanism that allows Member States to temporarily reinstate border controls in cases of emergency.
However, it remains to be seen how this will occur and whether the statements will be followed, above all, by concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to undertake a general reform of the European border protection system, particularly its external borders, ensuring that Frontex becomes as soon as possible an agency with genuine powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
Why must we protect our external borders if we want to continue with these things?
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not wish merely to survive.

The crisis has profoundly marked the lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering social quality, cultural heritage, well-being, the future of young people, and of Europeans.

Emerging from the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, for which, if necessary, even cutting back is required, establishing severe meta-financial regulations, remedies.

the recession, remedies against a development model that has placed the individual below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are now incumbent upon it.

It is always a matter of defining the tools, even new resources, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure, and employment, because without employment, people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Vaj Beèsese and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a proud and self-aware Europe.
To European leadership, if it exists, now it is a matter of implementing it.

The esteemed colleagues, the disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago has prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activity of offshore petroleum platforms.

aims to establish high safety standards and serves to enshrine the European Union’s leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.

in terms of procedures and liabilities, the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk diverting efforts from achieving concrete final objectives.

For all these reasons, I consider the result achieved through the renegotiation of this text, to which we have expressed our support, to be positive.

and although it remains uncertain whether the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are, as a percentage, in a much more limited quantity, there is no doubt that their potential is very high and that, therefore, we could truly achieve significant results within a few years, within a few decades, very.

Sir, within the single market, the free movement and the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements that have intervened independently of a modification of our way of legislating, both at the European and national levels.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions. In particular, it is necessary to genuinely initiate a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and individual States.

I would start directly from our documents, and I take this opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test on our documents. When we produce a white paper, a green paper, it all needs to be more comprehensible, and I would go so far as to say that the true proposal is perhaps strategically important for our Europe and to genuinely initiate [something].

Let this virtuous phase of legislative initiation be one where a specific delegation is assigned to a European Commissioner tasked specifically with clarifying legislation and relations between the states and Europe itself. Thank you.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I too would like to positively acknowledge, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package approved by the European Commission last June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon, and combating it requires measures of a European scope.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How to redress their grievance?

In many Member States, the political will to counter corruption has been lacking. Suffice it to say that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens’ rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it adopted to date by Member States are insufficient to contain a phenomenon in expansion.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and robust response, particularly now in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is weighing heavily on the lives of citizens, on the stability of pension and welfare systems, and on the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros annually, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily deprives the Union and its Member States of resources that
They would be utilized to provide fundamental services: education, early childhood, employment, transportation—in essence, to allocate clean resources to support individuals, people.

Therefore, it is necessary to have more courage and more resolve, both in monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and in intensifying and strengthening measures to counter corruption at the Union level.

Specifically, we cannot speak of combating corruption if we are not capable of adopting at least minimal standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member states, essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of contact points of the two EU Anti-Corruption Report Plus initiatives, as I proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
It is not recent; it has existed for several years.
Perhaps the time has come to undertake a critical assessment of the policies followed thus far. Everything has always been done well.
We have consistently conducted appropriate analyses of the situation.
The correct approach has been chosen.
The European Central Bank itself, which, as Minister Rostovski says, saved Europe, has always done well even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates.
President Barroso identifies a problem—the speed of markets and the slowness of policy—but is this the only problem?

Certainly, if one considers that we are still at the implementation stage of July 21st, this should at least suggest better preparation and organization of summits and their conclusions, but policy will always be slower than the markets.
Therefore, the point is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to the fight against unemployment and development.
This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more focus on the deficit and less on indications of growth and development.

The Commission must move beyond its weakness, stating that the priority is the fight against unemployment and job creation, wealth redistribution, and a public investment strategy, also changing the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr. President, I believe the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its previous primacy.
a world-class tourist destination while simultaneously enhancing its territorial heritage in terms of both environmental protection and competitive capacity.

It is a challenging and not guaranteed undertaking, even considering not only the opportunities but also the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, within this framework, as recalled by Commissioner Tajani, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the Commission that we approved in the Regional Development Committee.
It integrates a robust overarching strategy for the entire European Union on tourism with a valorization of the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, full engagement from the outset is essential, respecting the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting from the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
I also believe the proposal to identify a Europe brand that is capable of defining a high quality of tourism product is excellent.
Of course, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, particularly from a financial perspective, to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.
Sir, the preparation of a common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities facing European development and the European economy.

It is, in fact, a matter of acting on the lever that can genuinely trigger a moment of growth and also of new, qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to new opportunities in technology and related professions.
One observation that particularly emerges from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that lead to practical application, that actually arrive.
to foster new ventures that lead to new patents and that do not remain purely basic research, purely knowledge—important, yes, but not sufficient to truly trigger the development boom.

The second observation concerns the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for programming on the ground and for fostering dialogue between research institutions, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the European Schools were established with the aim of guaranteeing access to education in one’s mother tongue for the children of officials of the European institutions, required to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in 1953, at the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive aspects of this form of instruction, fourteen European schools have been established within the various member states.

While acknowledging that the European Schools system represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European School, such a system may exhibit obsolescent aspects and must, in some way, be adjusted and adapted to new economic and social needs.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by colleague Cavada, which aspires to a greater involvement of the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States called upon to work to develop and improve the system of European Schools.
It is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans, thank you, President.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, over the last few decades, the number of natural disasters has increased exponentially, causing the deaths of tens and thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the development committee, I followed the work on the report concerning the European Union’s capacity to respond to disasters.
there remained work to be done to guarantee a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the proliferation of earthquakes, floods, and tsunamis.
The European Union’s response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of existing instruments and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions have acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis has raised a number of issues concerning efficiency, coordination, and transparency.
For this reason, I express my favorable vote for the text of colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which envisions greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management and coordination.
among the involved parties and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlap and time wasted, which would hinder the provision of rapid and effective assistance.

The European brand is a good idea, but on two issues I want to elaborate: there is no tourism, let's say seaside or coastal tourism, without a policy of coastal planning.

I believe it is added that Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, produces an initiative in which the conception of the sea and the conception of the coasts are not limited to a sort of urban planning that ends at the dry changing room and does not comprehensively involve the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, as it will be necessary to construct everything underpinning the claims of rural tourism.
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where work no longer exists, where it is important to prevent further depopulation and encourage human settlement.

It is not enough merely to make statements, but rather to suggest to Europe and individual states that they intervene regarding the tax base. Promoting tourism in rural areas might mean paying lower taxes; perhaps this is how a genuine opportunity is truly built for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
Mr. President, I wish to express my congratulations on the work done by the Honorable Member, which logically fits within the framework of these actions.
undertakings and initiatives promoted at the Community level in the field of tourism, following the assignment of new competencies to the EU by the Treaty of Lisbon.
I share and wish to emphasize the assertion of the importance of a Europe with a unified destination for certified and quality tourism and the willingness to promote this.
the same idea, translating it into actions at the level of structures, allocations of resources, financing, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the Union’s countries.

an approach to be valued and rewarded, given the sector in question with its implications in terms of percentage of GDP produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Businesses demonstrating attention to the protection and enhancement of the environment are positioned to develop and, therefore, to respond to the primary challenges posed by contemporary realities.
For all these reasons, I believe this report to be positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European tourism policy.
Thank you, President, also for the recovery. Three small considerations: we need more Europe, even here.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain matters there will be a genuine attitude in which not only is it hoped for, but more Europe is actively built.
More Europe means, for example, genuinely beginning to consider a common highway patrol, with identical regulations from the perspective of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European education policy there, not simply delegating it to individual states, but building, for example, a genuine education policy.
With regard to schools, with regard to young people, and with regard to categories somewhat more at risk – I mentioned motorcyclists a moment ago, but we can also speak of truck drivers.
Europe means having common tools within vehicles that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol tools and anti-.
I believe they are a targeted strategy to be developed with automotive companies and European vehicle production.
I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honourable colleagues, this report addresses a theme concerning global food security. Global signifies that this theme is not solely that of world hunger, in the poorest countries, but that the issue of food supply pertains to all communities, including those in the most developed nations.

Outline some lines as the essential coherence between European policies and this objective of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well, but is often inconsistent in its choices.
I merely want to outline here the titles of three innovative lines that I believe we should develop further.
First, the procurement of food, today jeopardized by price volatility due to speculation on food products that must be contained if not prevented, derivatives, etc.
Secondly, the theme of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of negotiated treaty, is a threat to democracy as well as the survival of many peoples.
third, the coherence between procurement and energy policies.
We cannot, in producing new energy, prevent food from being produced for the world’s peoples.
I voted in favor of this report by Honorable Zimmer primarily for a reason of
a purely political matter because I believe it is necessary to bring this crucial issue of food security back to the center of the entire European Union's initiative.
It is not only and solely about helping developing countries to address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis is predicted to increase demand by over 70% from now until 2050.

The issue of migration is a significant matter that, if not addressed promptly and decisively, will become one of the primary threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace, and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is indispensable that the entire European Union, together with its member states, make every necessary effort, beginning with appropriate economic investments, as indicated in the report in this direction, to seriously address this significant issue.
Mr. to the Commission. I must truly thank all the people who contributed over these weeks, these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the Chamber.
We worked, I must say, very well, and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution we are voting on today, the culmination of genuinely shared work, is the result of the contribution of all political forces within the entire Parliament.

I believe that a shared and very strong sensitivity has developed regarding this topic, also because we must remember that we live in an era truly characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we consider them in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled if we consider that in 1975
Seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, whereas we are now experiencing almost 400 calamitous events per year.
In recent years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered 90 or more, and over 29 million individuals have been affected by them, while economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that they demand a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from our side.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan.
Europe itself witnesses on its territory every year sudden occurrences, fires, let us recall the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
It is necessary to go further to affirm how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
The fundamental principles that serve as our guiding stars: the principle of solidarity, strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving along these lines.

The European Union’s intervention has already consistently been generous and effective, as I believe the tireless work of our Commissioner Georgva attests, but today we need to take a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to one where the reaction
be strengthened through the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States, made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to highlight, for this qualitative leap and to transition from information sharing and emergency response to the role of planning and monitoring.
We hope for the coordination of services like GMS, and I take this opportunity to express the concern regarding what is happening with the budget, for these new technologies that are fundamental.
We have emphasized the importance of communication with citizens, because the Japanese experience has also taught us a great deal—it is never sufficient, it is never enough.
And we await from the Commission, which we request to present as soon as possible the proposal regarding civil protection in legislative form.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to practice their faith in secret, priests barbarically murdered without authorities lifting a finger, anti-Western foreign policy—this is Turkey today.
My party, the Lega Nord, has always been opposed to Turkey’s accession to Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism in our continent.
Today, more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must put an end to accession negotiations.
The irreconcilable threats posed by Turkey against Europe must have an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to dictate what Europe must do.
Cyprus is a member state recently admitted to the EU and has the unquestionable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and demonstrate its readiness to defend itself reciprocally by any means against the arrogance and military-political assertiveness of Turkey.
Let us immediately halt negotiations for accession and remain ready to suspend trade relations as well.
We are living through a decisive juncture for the future of the euro and, consequently, for the entirety of the European construction.
Truly possessing this awareness would mean escaping a myopic logic that subordinates everything to a narrow will for rigor and a balance sheet assessment.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, and we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without a judicious investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear outcome in this setup is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the most vulnerable segments of society.
Therefore, together with the Group of Socialists and Democrats, we voted against this report.
Indeed, progress continues in a single direction, that of rigidity without growth, a direction that has proven to be incorrect thus far.
appreciated the work done by colleague Ferrera on this report.
Indeed, regarding the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this did I and my group express a positive vote.

We have done so because a clause for the protection of social rights has been included, stemming from collective bargaining, and furthermore, there is a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while not being able to alter the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report undoubtedly represents a step forward, among other things, toward establishing a surveillance system that takes into account fundamental rights.

Therefore, in this context, while maintaining that, in our judgment, a vision based solely on austerity policies does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive and counter-trend note.

Honourable colleagues, Finland and Iceland have taken a seat on the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are currently unable to guarantee effective border controls and are plagued by rampant corruption involving the political class and organised crime.
It is not the parties or populist movements that think this way, but rather the Aeropol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is some populist propaganda, but a serious security issue.

Should Bulgaria enter the Raschengue at this moment, law enforcement and security agencies anticipate that Bulgarian borders, particularly the maritime ones, would become easy targets for Turkish and Eastern European criminal activity, and Bulgaria and Romania would become focal points for human trafficking and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations regarding the real capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to guarantee effective controls at the borders against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders precisely where there is intense migratory pressure from Turkey.
There are many opposing reasons, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore request to know the intentions of those advising omission regarding this delicate matter, which, in my view, has been treated until now with superficiality.
sufficiency and without considering the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies regarding security and international crime.

In my view, the commission and the council should postpone the accession of these two countries to Schengen and give the green light only when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions for the security of European citizens.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the crisis in Europe is intertwining the problems of public finances and private capital with those of the productivity of our businesses, and the spectre of recession looms.
Therefore, if the priority of the PII is crucial, I ask the Commission to absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that our good principles are put in.
and that the legislative initiatives of sbaDE and the Small Business Act become concrete practice for Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Do you think, Commissioner, what it would not be if all Member States were to bring forward the implementation of the directive against late payments? What a great advantage it would be for SMEs? Then SME proof tests are important, but we are still at a methodological level.

It is simply necessary to verify that when we implement [measures], we truly do so in the interest and to the scale of small and medium-sized enterprises. However, we request that the process proceed with great consistency and tenacity, delving deeply into creating the framework of opportunities you have outlined.
We appreciate what is being done by the Commission as well, and we are ready, with the budget and other possibilities at our disposal, to support it.
I will say just one word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say this to you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text proposed by my colleague, the honorable Wallis.

Without prejudice to the usual avenues for access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) process represents a rapid and cost-effective alternative to legal proceedings.
Beyond being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also experience considerable online development for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through a joint activity with Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens’ trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the report concerning the regulation for market entrants and the flexibility regime to which we have expressed our favourable vote was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

concretized on the one hand by avoiding the establishment of excessively onerous and impossible-to-satisfy requirements and, on the other, by establishing a so-called flexibility regime that articulates itself through the provision of temporal phases and corresponding quantitative limits.

permitted emissions, anticipates the issuance onto the market of a pre-established annual quota of tractors meeting specific characteristics and thereby allows for the gradual adaptation to stipulated standards without disruption to the interested productive and industrial sectors.

The work accomplished has been important; he has demonstrated an astute balance between the needs dictated by the significant challenges facing the European Union at this time, and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade imbalances between countries, financial markets lacking common regulation, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently emphasizes the establishment of new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy requires a global governance system for open markets, high economic and social standards, a more responsible monetary policy, and stricter supervisory policies; decision-making bodies, economic organizations, and international institutions must be the principal actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, specifically, needs a network to reduce the exacerbated instabilities, also stemming from globalization, and to guarantee far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has been increasingly subject to unjust political attacks.
His arrest warrants have often been disregarded, and consequently, the current balance does not reflect the effort and commitment expended.

I have therefore cast my favorable vote for the text approved today because it is the duty of the European Union to undertake all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and proper, effective functioning.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, the phosphates present in household washing machine detergents end up in European waterways, rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of various life forms. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus presence in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algal growth depletes oxygen for other living organisms, can also produce toxins destroying fish and plant species, thereby reducing the quality of the water itself.

I have therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text voted on today because it is desirable to reduce the quantity of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent to purify Europe’s water resources.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the European Union has produced a vast quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the single market.
There is a discordance between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the utilization made of it by citizens, which is numerically and proportionally very low.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of individual states have grown within the law of their own country and possess a predominantly formative background in that legal system.
while we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before discussing training, it is necessary to address a broad communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they may become proponents of this significant development and foster the desire to utilize the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a movement that must be created from the ground up within in-service training. One cannot conduct lessons as if addressing schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults and professionals of considerable stature.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity when dealing with one's own cases, to connect with other colleagues, and to find solutions, given that today common law and civil law converge and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has become convinced of these aspects within our convention, we are requesting a bottom-up shift, more legal studies than judicial training.

There exists an example in olananda called euinfra, which is very interesting: it is a network of responsible parties in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage the magistrates in this regard.
Herein lies the essence of our project; we hope it will receive the commission’s full support.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I would like to express, first of all, a very sincere appreciation for the work done by colleague Gigol on this report of initiative, and I also recall that with him and with others we share an active presence in the intergroup for the social economy of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the foundational characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

These days, with attacks also linked to necessities, cuts in public spending, etcetera, we still defend this conviction. We know it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that within this same perspective, we must also value economic actors who engage in business and the production of goods and services, such as cooperatives, and who have a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

It is asserted that production can be undertaken, good things can be achieved, one can be efficient, even if profit is not the objective, but rather, for example, that of employment, welfare, the enhancement of labor, and the contribution to the life of the local community.

Therefore, it is important to conclude, President, that Europe makes available the tools useful for a proactive policy and to draft a sound statute, not the current one which is unusable, but a sound statute for cooperatives can be a way to help this sector so important.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and more equitable economic dimension.
At this moment, as we navigate one of the most severe economic and social crises since the post-war period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial. It is, in fact, evident that the
A robust development of the cooperative dimension within the economy has consequently resulted in increased employment, more skilled labor, and a more balanced redistribution of wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be genuine simplification of the rules.
We need to reinvigorate the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must occur by providing assistance and not erecting bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason, I voted in favor of this reconsideration, and I hope that the committee and the Council will actively work to resolve the issues cited.

The plight of the millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the faltering assistance offered by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; data collected reveal that the majority of the Fund’s beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while those more fortunate are reintegrated into the labour market with fixed-term contracts, sometimes lasting only six months.
In many cases, it is the unemployed who forgo this fund, doubting its usefulness.
The feigo is not a solution and does not address the devastating consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously with excessive carelessness by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of now structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose competition is the primary cause of the failures of our companies.
Until Europe ceases to promote economic self-harm, defending a short-sighted position regarding global trade flows, our businesses will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training costs that our unemployed will find serenity and security.

voted in favor of the present proposal, as it aims to update the 2004 and 2009 regulations to adapt national legislation changes to the Member States in the field of social security and to keep pace with the changes in social reality that affect the coordination of those security systems.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law.

Bearing in mind the importance of mutual recognition of the harmonization of protective regulations, the principle of presumption of innocence, it is advisable to emphasize how the law must be of utmost clarity and easily comprehensible, so as to make clear to all which actions constitute a crime.
This is particularly true for directives that must be equivalent to national law.
Any lack of clarity may indeed give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law, thank you.

a strategy directed at the protection of the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in anticipation of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union has been granting economic aid to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties, in the form of grants, loans, or a combination of both.
The rather lengthy timelines, compounded by the difficulties evident in the decision-making criteria used thus far, have made it necessary to formulate some amendments to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulations, which aims to make assessment criteria faster and more effective, and to establish clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.

Volunteering represents one of the most extensive expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I anticipate the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of the obstacles currently in place.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, from the field of communications to finance, transportation, energy, culture, and healthcare, the role played by technology is increasingly relevant.
The increasingly frequent use of the internet and digital media makes cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed foster economic and social development only if existing regulations guarantee user security regarding data privacy and intellectual property rights.
For this, only full international cooperation involving Member States, institutions, and industry can give rise to a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.

It appears that the spirit of revitalization and a renewed path toward political unity is returning to European institutions after so much slowness and torpor, along with a willingness to achieve tangible progress toward greater integration.
We have recorded strong unity between Parliament and the Commission on this matter.

I am not speaking of winning events, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past hierarchy, which was the negation, the antithesis of community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not already to establish new exclusionary axes, but to construct a common consensus respectful of all member states.
This is the path to the political goal of Unity, without which every banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be entirely insufficient.
June, with the Council's decision to grant member states the possibility of reinstating controls and borders, has ushered in a new Europe—a Europe courageous in fulfilling the desire
Greater security for its citizens is finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, brought back to the defense of their peoples above all.

To the President, even though you are not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional incident but rather respect for the will of the citizens and that Euroburocracy which pretends not to understand what truly happens outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of irregular migrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants measured by Frontex of 35 percent in 2011.

If Parliament fails to find its own identity and the courage to go against the sentimentality and sterile platitudes upon which it has long floundered, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not file a report due to fear or a lack of trust in the institutions.

all countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Their declarations are a very serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy which we preach and should defend here.
I tell them that the peoples will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The path is already laid out.

Sustaining growth and employment will be possible by rebalancing the economies of member states and improving the situation of European citizens.
