Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014–2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to implementing fiscal adjustments and their respective national budgets to replenish public finances, the European Union is, in some cases, perceived as an entity that exacerbates the financial burden on taxpayers.

Therefore, to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of education and development.
This represents the programmatic document of an institution; from its budget, one understands what it is, what it does, and, above all, what it intends to do in the future.

We are facing a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of mere existence, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective investment choices for employment, for innovation for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

All should understand that, as colleague Kalfin has very clearly stated among others, Europe can do today what states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for territories, where social cohesion is affirmed or where the lives of citizens – of whom we have spoken – are undermined.
Major European decisions risk being stifled today by philosophical debates within the Council, but not only between beneficiary, payer, and paying countries.

We argue that this is a false problem, because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, based on what has happened in the past, that the contributor countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working to assign figures to the various categories.

The war of positions has begun: statements, declarations of position from some states that regard the budget as just any expenditure item, which can be reduced and without remorse, indeed perhaps useful to bolster a sentiment, even a European one, easily aroused in times of economic crisis.
It is a misguided position that does not aid the integration we are striving for in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as we have said so many times.
We adopted a stability pact that was also meant to foster development, but we have become so stabilized that we are in recession.
Let us at least seize the opportunity offered by this budget, this multi-year framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness of one's rights, compounded by obstacles.

Linguistic issues and the failure to recognize diplomas or qualifications are the most common problems encountered by citizens of the Union when residing, studying, or working in another country of the European Union.
Unfortunately, there remains a lack of visibility regarding the concept of Union citizenship and its tangible benefits.
For this reason, I expressed my support for 2013 as European Year of Citizens.

Mr. Presidenteghi, the Brussels I Regulation undoubtedly represented one of the most effective acts of the
legislation of the Union, as it outlined the foundations of a European judicial space and promoted legal certainty among European citizens.
The dissemination of this regulation touches upon fundamental themes for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules regarding
on the jurisdiction of disputes involving parties domiciled in third countries and agreements concerning the selection of the competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can guarantee more robust consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today you have requested from Europe a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most rigorous proponents of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, even in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not merely excess production capacity and dramatic job losses.
But the crisis now appears structural and concerns the destiny of the automobile and the product as it exists today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing existing expertise, know-how, and professional skills.
We therefore request that a major project of restructuring and revitalization be initiated, and that it not be rushed, as costs are proportional to the timeframe.
Restructuring cannot be merely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual enterprises.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
Trade unions and national governments, offering support through research, innovation, human capital development, reskilling, and the necessary funding.
I know it will be a difficult endeavor because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash currently underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I believe that ultimately, it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective impetus and communal guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive global market.
The energy crisis has inflicted and continues to inflict a very high price on all employment, affecting thousands of precarious, stable, and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The largest steel groups are increasingly oriented towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a significant question regarding the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must rediscover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

And I believe that we need to emerge from a dualism that hasn’t been fully elucidated here tonight, but which is often felt in discussions on this sector—a dualism between environmental advocates and workers—which is mistaken because it prevents us from seeing a perspective for the future.
An industry that views steelmaking as an integral part requires advanced production systems, balanced solutions that safeguard diverse interests and needs.

Therefore, a strong European planning effort is also underway, one that focuses on sustainability – a principle on which, in my view, we must not regress – as a key added value with which we intend to compete globally, supporting investments as we have done.

More new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants, for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, even those energetic, indeed starting from those energetic, and also on the research of new and different materials.

The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

A supranational structure such as the IITU, of which we know hundreds of States from around the world are members, many of whom are known for issues relating to democratic principles, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to consider the pillars of the internet—freedom, participation, openness, innovation—to be at risk.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to safeguard the role of the internet and the role that, especially, the internet can play in revitalizing economic growth, but also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission works towards the goal of Europe, Dubai being united and speaking with a single voice.

Numerous controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiation table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envision modifications to internet governance that challenge net neutrality—all of which are detrimental to consumers.
Therefore, the freedom of the internet—or more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection—is at risk.
What some states have proposed would, in fact, allow a government to intrude not only on the communications of its own citizens, but even on the data transiting their networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it contradicts the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text proposed by the colleague. In particular, I concur with the rapporteur in highlighting the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in judicial matters for judicial and administrative legal authorities for legal professionals.
Furthermore, all sector initiatives should be intensified to fully realize the concept of the Union founded on the rule of law.

Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that today’s occasion should be used to discuss with objectivity Kazakhstan’s and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country because it concerns the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undoubtedly an important economic and commercial component of the European Union.

This is a country that has already initiated a reform process concerning economics and also a democratic process, but which still needs to commit itself significantly to bringing these processes to full completion.

However, it is a country that, with this objective, continues to demonstrate its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that this is the task of the European Union to accompany them.

European, and for this I am certain that the signature of this strengthened agreement will allow for progress, because its approval will reinforce an already solid and productive relationship and ensure consistent assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been further emphasized in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that improvement in progress towards democracy, rights, and human dignity must be accompanied by a renewed, reciprocal, open, and constructive commitment.

Our objective should not be to adopt a negative stance towards these other countries in light of the immediate failure to implement changes. Our objective should be to support these countries’ efforts to achieve the goal, including respect for the principles of human rights.

Mr. President, colleagues, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, in wishing to thank the speakers for the reports we will vote on tomorrow, just a brief passage on spin and I concur with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
I shall refrain from dwelling on amateur fishing and the Ferrera relationship, which I greet and with which I offer my compliments.

I wished to say that with the past common policy on fishing, we have only contributed to increasing the disconnect between the institutions that regulate fishing and its true stakeholders, including the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now, in Europe the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

It is in this way that the conviction dries that the line pursued by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen for a couple of

For decades, regulations have been in place that pertain to the preservation of the ecosystem, with which I can only agree, but which have never protected the working activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This report on the initiative sends a strong signal to the Commission and may translate into further practical benefits for the small-scale fishing economy.
The report, in fact, highlights a series of benefits from the allocation of a minimum sum to small-scale fisheries by the European Fund.

It will be necessary to incentivize projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole, and furthermore, Commissioner, encouraging access for young people will be indispensable.

We have discussed this several times in Committee, because otherwise not only will fishing likely die out through depletion of the seas and fish, but it will likely die out because young people no longer approach this sector.
This report provides an opportunity to incorporate formative moments and initial exposure for young people wishing to enter the sector.

To minimize it, to freeze its future.
But it is that same Europe that now seeks to revitalize itself with the Varro Report on integration.
But with what consistency do I then ask you to handle these two dossiers?

And what coherence can citizens discern between the decisions of July and employment and growth, the insistent calls and the hope for the future of the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, then, in the name of realism, from a perspective of minimal survival.

How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to translate the much-vaunted major reforms of cohesion and the [European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development] into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions; we would like a clear, honest answer, because here we see the signs of an institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament desires consistency; it desires credibility.

The first criticism is that we simply aren't on par regarding the budget; forget about growth and job investments, we're at the 2008 budget level. It must be acknowledged, however, that concerning rubric 1a, Varro's proposal overturns the scandalous Cypriot hypothesis.
It is true, here the role of the budget is recognized as an irreplaceable driver of growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But whether it be growth or innovation, it must be clear that it should not be at the expense of other sectors, which are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy, and also, dear colleagues, such as agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of territory.
Grove Jobs encompasses culture, training, transnational networks, the CEF, and also solidarity and international development, human rights worldwide, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, however, unfortunately, is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a cacophony of national interests, opposed and competing with one another, an inextricable knot of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
Europe, unfortunately, is the notable absence.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, bycatch is an environmentally unacceptable practice as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species that depend on this
social and economic, and because it involves the waste of a foodstuff with commercial value, as well as from an ethical standpoint, since it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption from the ban on removing shark fins on board fishing vessels of the Union.

This proposal, in addition to further guaranteeing sharks the protection they require, will thus allow the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
